 Credit is limited only by calculated and perceived ability to service the debt. While credit facilities between trading nations (sovereign treasury issues) skirt eventual repayment of capital, that's generally an issue determined by strength of currency and economic future. I see no true US economic expansion in the foreseeable future, as attested to by our abnormal trade deficits, with US international credit facilitated by our trading partners determined to keep us afloat until our valuable markets can be replaced by emerging nations, China in particular. To do otherwise would be disastrous to their economies. Personal US debt will continue to follow national debt for as long as it can be serviced, which is dependent on US employment and the share of median income it distributes to lower and middle income classes. 
 
 To depend on Bush's 'Peace Dividend' for future prosperity seems, to me, like the beginning of a really bad acid trip culminating in a ferocious crash. But since I don't use 25% of my personal income to service interest expenses and another 25% investing in depreciating assets similar to vehicles or a military, I'd probably be labeled as unpatriotic by those who elect indulgence in political and personal financial hallucinogens.
